summary_points: 1. Cardinal Health's GAAP operating earnings increased by 98% year-over-year to $730 million in the period ending March 31, 2025, but this is partially offset by the negative impact of expired OptumRx contracts, with some continuing impact expected through the remainder of fiscal year 2025.
2.  In the first quarter of 2025, Cardinal Health spent $765 million on treasury stock repurchases, with plans for an additional $250 million, and recorded a $90 million goodwill impairment.
3.  Cardinal Health completed three significant acquisitions in the last six months of 2024 and the first four months of 2025: ION ($1.1 billion), GIA ($2.8 billion), and ADSG ($1.1 billion).

1. Conagra Brands sold its Chef Boyardee shelf-stable product line (excluding frozen skillet meals, which will be licensed) to Hometown Food Company for $600 million in cash, a transaction expected to close in Q1 of fiscal year 2026.
2.  The divested Chef Boyardee products contributed approximately $450 million to Conagra's fiscal year 2024 net sales.

3. Conagra estimates that, had the sale closed at the start of fiscal year 2025, it would have been approximately four percent dilutive to adjusted earnings per share for the year, excluding transaction costs.
1. Pinnacle West Capital Corp. experienced a significant swing from a $16.9 million net income in Q1 2024 to a $4.6 million net loss in Q1 2025.
2.  APS's outstanding commercial paper borrowings increased to $627 million as of May 1st, 2025, following a $400 million drawdown.
3. Pinnacle West anticipates $14.8 billion in fixed consideration from energy storage lease arrangements between April 2025 and June 2028.
1. Pinnacle West Capital Corp. reported a net loss of $4.6 million in Q1 2025, compared to a net income of $16.9 million in Q1 2024.
2. APS retail customer growth (2.3%) outpaced retail sales growth (2.1%) in Q1 2025.
3.  The company projects weather-normalized consolidated earnings per diluted share between $4.40 and $4.60 for 2025.
1.  Intercontinental Exchange, Inc.'s effective tax rate rose to 24% in Q1 2025, up from 19% in Q1 2024, due to a decrease in deferred tax benefits.
2.  The company repurchased $241 million of its common stock in Q1 2025 and has $2.28 billion remaining for future repurchases as of March 31, 2025.
3.  ICE expects to spend between $730 million and $780 million on capital expenditures and software development in 2025.
1. Kellanova's Q1 2025 operating profit increased 9% year-over-year, but currency-neutral adjusted operating profit decreased by 11%, highlighting the impact of foreign exchange rates.
2.  Kellanova's proposed merger with Acquiror 10VB8, LLC, is expected to close by August 13, 2025, with potential termination fees of up to $1.25 billion.
3.  Kellanova's Noodles and other product category showed a 20% year-over-year increase in net sales during Q1 2025, reaching $251 million.
1. W.W. Grainger, Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 sales were $4.3 billion, a 1.7% increase year-over-year,  but a 4.4% increase on a daily, constant currency basis.
2. Despite a slight year-over-year decrease in operating margin (from 15.8% to 15.6%), diluted earnings per share increased by 2.5% to $9.86.
3.  Grainger reaffirmed its full-year 2025 guidance on May 1st, 2025, projecting net sales between $17.6 and $18.1 billion, with daily, constant currency sales growth of 4.0% to 6.5%.

1. At BorgWarner Inc.'s annual meeting on April 30, 2025, a stockholder proposal to remove the one-year holding requirement to call a special meeting was rejected by a significant margin (33,325,712 for, 154,390,112 against).
2.  A quarterly cash dividend of $0.11 per share was declared on April 30, 2025, payable on June 16, 2025, to stockholders of record on June 2, 2025.

3. The advisory vote on executive compensation received significantly less support than the vote to ratify the selection of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor (162,633,360 for, versus 194,875,100 for).
1. Kellanova's reported net sales decreased by 3.6% year-over-year to $3,083 million in the first quarter of 2025, while organic net sales increased by 0.7%.
2.  Adjusted operating profit decreased by 13.1% year-over-year, and adjusted diluted earnings per share decreased by 10.9%, primarily due to higher costs and adverse business mix.
3. Kellanova's acquisition by Mars, Incorporated, is expected to close within the first half of 2025, subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals.

1. Mastercard reported first-quarter 2025 net revenue of $7.3 billion, a 14% year-over-year increase (17% on a currency-neutral basis), driven by growth in its payment network and value-added services.

2.  The effective tax rate for Q1 2025 was 18.6% (19.1% adjusted), higher than the 15.4% (15.9% adjusted) in Q1 2024, primarily due to the implementation of the 15% global minimum tax ("Pillar 2 Rules").
3. As of April 28, 2025, Mastercard had $11.8 billion remaining under its approved share repurchase programs.

1. As of May 1, 2025, Estée Lauder Companies reported a 10% decrease in net sales to $3.6 billion, with organic net sales down 9% year-over-year, primarily due to declines in the Asia/Pacific region and global travel retail.

2.  The company's Profit Recovery and Growth Plan (PRGP), which aims to restore double-digit adjusted operating margins, is expected to incur between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion in restructuring charges before taxes, resulting in a net reduction of 5,800 to 7,000 positions.

3. The company forecasts a stronger double-digit decline in global travel retail net sales and a high-single-digit organic net sales decline in Asia/Pacific for the fiscal 2025 fourth quarter (ending June 30, 2025), impacting full-year adjusted EPS.
1. Hubbell Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 diluted earnings per share (EPS) of $3.15 and adjusted diluted EPS of $3.50, compared to adjusted diluted EPS of $3.60 in the first quarter of 2024.

2.  First-quarter 2025 net sales decreased by 2% year-over-year, primarily due to a 15% decrease in Grid Automation sales, offset by continued strong performance in Electrical Solutions (5% organic growth) and a return to organic growth in Grid Infrastructure.

3. For the full year 2025, Hubbell anticipates total sales growth of 6-8%, with diluted EPS projected in the range of $15.95-$16.45 and adjusted diluted EPS in the range of $17.35-$17.85 (as of May 1, 2025).
1. As of March 31, 2025, Broadridge Financial Solutions reported diluted EPS of $2.05, a 15% increase year-over-year, despite a significant 11% year-over-year decrease in closed sales.
2. Broadridge lowered its FY2025 closed sales guidance by $50-$80 million, to a range of $240-$300 million.
3.  The Q3 2025 11% year-over-year decrease in closed sales suggests a potential $50-$80 million reduction in FY25 revenue and earnings.
1. Parker Hannifin Corp. reported record margins (23.2% reported, 26.3% adjusted) and diluted earnings per share of $7.37 for the quarter ending March 31, 2025.
2.  While net income increased by 32% year-over-year (to $961 million), adjusted net income only grew by 6% (to $904 million) for the quarter ending March 31, 2025.

3. As of May 1, 2025, Parker Hannifin forecasts a net 1% decrease in sales for fiscal year 2025, due to a projected 1% organic sales growth being offset by a 2% decrease from divestitures and currency headwinds.

1. Air Products & Chemicals, Inc. reported a GAAP net loss of $1.7 billion for the second quarter of fiscal year 2025 (ending March 31, 2025), compared to a GAAP net income of $581 million in the same quarter of 2024, primarily due to a $2.3 billion after-tax charge for business and asset actions.
2.  Adjusted EPS for Q2 FY25 was $2.69, a 6% decrease year-over-year.
3.  Air Products revised its full-year fiscal 2025 adjusted EPS guidance to $11.85 to $12.15, and Q3 FY25 adjusted EPS guidance to $2.90 to $3.00.
1. Fortive Corp. plans to spin off its Precision Technologies segment as Ralliant Corporation by the end of Q2 2025.
2. Fortive's Q1 2025 sales decreased by 3.3% year-over-year, driven by a 1.7% core revenue decline and currency headwinds.
3. New U.S. tariffs and resulting retaliatory tariffs pose a significant risk to Fortive's financial performance through supply chain disruptions and increased costs.

1. Fortive Corp's Q1 2025 revenue decreased 3% year-over-year to $1.47 billion, including a 2% core revenue decline, primarily due to delayed customer investments in the Precision Technologies segment.

2.  Adjusted diluted net EPS for Q1 2025 was $0.85, in line with expectations, while full-year 2025 adjusted diluted net EPS guidance is now $3.80 to $4.00, reflecting moderated demand and tariff impacts.

3. Fortive plans to separate from Ralliant by the end of Q2 2025, subject to conditions including board approval, financing, legal opinions, and regulatory approvals; Ralliant's Form 10 registration statement is anticipated to be filed in early May 2025.
1. Dominion Energy's Q1 2025 GAAP net income was $646 million ($0.75 per share), a significant increase from $441 million ($0.50 per share) in Q1 2024.

2.  For the first quarter of 2025, operating earnings (non-GAAP) were $803 million ($0.93 per share), compared to $485 million ($0.55 per share) in Q1 2024, representing a substantial year-over-year increase.
3. Dominion Energy affirmed its full-year 2025 operating earnings guidance range of $3.28 to $3.52 per share as of May 1, 2025.
1. Intercontinental Exchange, Inc. (ICE) reported record net revenues of $2.5 billion for the first quarter of 2025, an 8% year-over-year increase.
2.  ICE's adjusted diluted earnings per share (EPS) for the first quarter of 2025 increased by 16% year-over-year to $1.72.

3.  ICE provided second-quarter 2025 financial guidance, projecting GAAP operating expenses between $1.230 billion and $1.240 billion, and adjusted operating expenses between $980 million and $990 million.
1. As of April 30, 2025, News Corporation had repurchased approximately US$667,422,863.38 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On April 30, 2025,  21,691,841 Class A shares and 10,706,705 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$442,339,246.74 and US$224,481,092.04 respectively.
3. News Corporation's stock repurchase program, authorized to acquire up to $1 billion of outstanding shares, has a remaining authorization of approximately US$332,577,136.62 as of May 1, 2025.

1. Baxter International Inc. exceeded its previously issued guidance for first-quarter 2025 sales and adjusted diluted earnings per share, reporting sales of $2.63 billion (a 5% increase) and adjusted diluted EPS of $0.55.
2.  For the full year 2025, Baxter now expects adjusted diluted EPS of $2.47 to $2.55,  a slight increase from the prior guidance of $2.45 to $2.55.
3. Baxter projects second-quarter 2025 sales growth of 4% to 5% on a reported basis and 1% to 2% on an operational basis.
1. Despite a 2.5% year-over-year decrease in first-quarter 2025 revenues to $2.7 billion, HII's operating income increased by 7.6% to $526 million.
2.  HII's first-quarter 2025 diluted earnings per share show conflicting year-over-year results; a decrease to $3.79 in one section, and an increase to $5.61 in another.
3.  HII projects full-year 2025 revenues between $10.0 and $10.2 billion, an increase from the prior year, while anticipating free cash flow between $300 and $500 million.
1. Linde plc's Q1 2025 adjusted operating profit margin significantly increased by 120 basis points year-over-year, reaching 30.1%.
2.  Despite flat overall sales, Linde plc's underlying sales increased by 1% year-over-year in Q1 2025.
3.  Linde plc projects a 4% to 6% (6% to 8% excluding currency effects) increase in adjusted diluted earnings per share for the full year 2025, as of May 1st, 2025.
1. AvalonBay Communities, Inc. made a significant property acquisition in Dallas-Fort Worth, totaling $431,500,000 in April 2025, partially financed with DownREIT Units.
2.  AvalonBay Communities, Inc. exited the Connecticut market in Q1 2025, selling one property for $65,100,000.
3. For Q2 2025, AvalonBay projects diluted EPS between $1.78 and $1.88 per share and diluted Core FFO between $2.72 and $2.82 per share.
1. Church & Dwight's Q1 2025 net sales decreased 2.4% to $1,467.1 million, missing the company's projected 1% growth, primarily due to slower US category growth and retailer inventory reductions.

2.  The company projects a 12-month run-rate gross tariff exposure of approximately $190 million, but expects to reduce this by about 80% through portfolio decisions (divesting businesses generating $150 million in net sales) and supply chain adjustments.

3.  Church & Dwight revised its 2025 full-year outlook, anticipating 0% to 2% organic sales growth (previously 3% to 4%), a 60 basis point adjusted gross margin contraction (previously a 25 basis point increase), and 0% to 2% adjusted EPS growth (previously 7% to 8%), primarily due to continued retailer destocking, slower category growth, and tariff pressures.
1. Eli Lilly's Q1 2025 revenue increased 45% year-over-year to $12.73 billion, primarily driven by Mounjaro and Zepbound sales volume growth.
2.  Q1 2025 earnings per share (EPS) increased 23% to $3.06 (reported) and 29% to $3.34 (non-GAAP),  though both figures include significant acquired IPR&D charges ($1.72 per share).

3. Eli Lilly's full-year 2025 EPS guidance decreased to $20.17-$21.67 (reported) and $20.78-$22.28 (non-GAAP) due to acquired IPR&D charges and net losses on investments, despite reaffirmed revenue guidance of $58.0-$61.0 billion.
1. McDonald's US comparable sales saw a significant 3.6% year-over-year decline in Q1 2025, even after adjusting for Leap Day.
2.  Global comparable sales for Q1 2025 were essentially flat after adjusting for Leap Day.
3. McDonald's projects over 2% systemwide sales growth for 2025, entirely driven by approximately 2,200 new restaurant openings.
1. Teleflex Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 revenue decreased by 5.0% year-over-year to $700.7 million, while adjusted diluted EPS decreased by 9.3%.
2. Despite increased full-year 2025 GAAP revenue guidance (1.28% to 2.28%), adjusted diluted EPS guidance was lowered to $13.20 to $13.60 due to tariffs and separation costs.
3. Teleflex Inc. is exploring strategic options for its NewCo subsidiary, including a potential sale.
1. IDEX Corporation reported record orders of $872 million for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, a 6% increase compared to the same period in 2024, but only 1% organic growth.
2.  Despite record orders, diluted EPS decreased by 21% to $1.26 and adjusted diluted EPS decreased by 7% to $1.75 for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, compared to the same period in 2024.

3. IDEX Corporation anticipates full-year 2025 organic sales growth of 1% to 3% and GAAP diluted EPS of $6.56-$6.95 (adjusted diluted EPS of $8.10-$8.45), incorporating an additional $20 million in cost containment to offset potential tariff-related volume pressure.

1. As of May 1, 2025, Builders FirstSource, Inc. reported a 6% year-over-year decrease in net sales to $3.7 billion for the first quarter of 2025, primarily due to lower organic sales and commodity deflation.
2.  The company's free cash flow decreased by 80.2% year-over-year to $45 million for the first quarter of 2025.
3. Builders FirstSource's Board of Directors authorized a $500 million share repurchase plan on May 1, 2025, adding to the approximately $100 million remaining from a prior authorization.
1. Quanta Services, Inc. reported record first-quarter 2025 revenues of $6.2 billion, a significant increase from $5.03 billion in the first quarter of 2024.

2.  For the full year 2025, Quanta raised its revenue expectations to a range of $26.7 billion to $27.2 billion, and adjusted diluted earnings per share are projected to range between $10.05 and $10.65.

3. Quanta's positive long-term outlook is tempered by concerns about weather, regulatory hurdles, supply chain issues, trade policies, macroeconomic challenges and potential recessionary conditions that could affect project timing and execution.
1. Exelon's Q1 2025 earnings per share increased significantly year-over-year, from $0.66 (GAAP) and $0.68 (adjusted) in Q1 2024 to $0.90 (GAAP) and $0.92 (adjusted) in Q1 2025.
2. As of May 1, 2025, Exelon had secured 60% of its projected $700 million annual equity financing target.
3. Exelon projects 6% or higher operating EPS compounded annual growth from 2024 to 2028.

1. Carrier Global Corporation reported strong first-quarter 2025 results on May 1, 2025, with adjusted EPS up 27% year-over-year to $0.65, driven by strong productivity and pricing, despite a 4% decline in net sales due to a prior-year divestiture.
2.  As of May 1, 2025, Carrier increased its full-year 2025 adjusted earnings per share guidance, projecting $3.00-$3.10, a 17-21% increase year-over-year.

3.  On May 1, 2025, Carrier implemented revised reportable segments and a new segment profitability measure (Segment operating profit), affecting only segment results and not the company's previously reported consolidated financial information.

1. Biogen Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 total revenue was $2.4 billion, a 6% year-over-year increase (8% at constant currency), driven partly by the timing of SPINRAZA shipments and growth from newer products more than doubling year-over-year.
2.  First-quarter 2025 GAAP diluted EPS was $1.64, a 39% decrease from $2.70 in the first quarter of 2024, while non-GAAP diluted EPS decreased by 18% to $3.02.

3. Biogen updated its full-year 2025 Non-GAAP diluted EPS guidance to $14.50 to $15.50, reflecting a ~$0.95 decrease due to a $165 million upfront payment to Stoke Therapeutics and a $0.20 increase from more favorable foreign exchange; total revenue is expected to decline by a mid-single-digit percentage at constant currency compared to 2024.
1. Aptiv PLC reported a first-quarter 2025 U.S. GAAP loss of $0.05 per diluted share, but excluding special items, earnings totaled $1.69 per diluted share.
2.  First-quarter 2025 U.S. GAAP revenue was $4.8 billion, a 2% decrease year-over-year, while adjusted revenue (excluding currency and commodity impacts) decreased by 1%.
3. Aptiv's full-year 2025 financial guidance does not account for potential impacts from U.S. government tariffs or retaliatory actions from other countries.
1. Cardinal Health's Q3 FY2025 revenue was $54.9 billion, flat year-over-year, but increased 19% excluding a previously announced customer contract expiration.
2. Non-GAAP diluted EPS increased 13% year-over-year to $2.35 in Q3 FY2025, driven by segment profit growth across all operating segments.
3. Cardinal Health raised its FY2025 non-GAAP EPS guidance to $8.05-$8.15 (from $7.85-$8.00) and anticipates double-digit non-GAAP EPS growth in FY2026.
1. Iron Mountain's Q1 2025 revenue was reported inconsistently across sections, ranging from $1.4 billion to $1.6 billion,  with conflicting year-over-year growth rates.
2. While Q1 2025 revenue showed growth, net income significantly decreased year-over-year, dropping from $77 million to as low as $16 million, primarily attributed to exchange rate fluctuations.
3. Iron Mountain projects approximately 11% year-over-year revenue growth for the full year 2025 and plans a $500 million common stock repurchase.

1. Hershey's first-quarter 2025 consolidated net sales decreased 13.8% to $2,805.4 million, compared to the first quarter of 2024, primarily due to lower sales volume driven by the lap of planned inventory increases in 2024 and the timing of Easter.
2.  The company projects a high-40% decrease in reported earnings per share and a mid-30% decrease in adjusted earnings per share for the full year 2025, as of May 1, 2025.

3.  For the second quarter of 2025, Hershey anticipates tariff expenses of approximately $15 million to $20 million, but their full-year guidance excludes assumptions about future tariffs beyond Q2 2025.
1. Smurfit Westrock's Q1 2025 net sales increased dramatically year-over-year, from $2,930 million to $7,656 million.
2.  The company anticipates $100 million in economic downtime in Q2 2025 due to facility closures, resulting in a slight decrease in adjusted EBITDA compared to Q1 2025.
3. Smurfit Westrock projects full-year 2025 adjusted EBITDA to be between $5.0 and $5.2 billion, as of May 1st, 2025.
1. CVS Health's Q1 2025 net income attributable to CVS Health was $1,779 million, a 59.8% increase compared to Q1 2024.

2.  The company divested its MSSP operations and exited the ACO REACH program in Q1 2025, resulting in a $247 million loss on Accountable Care assets and a $236 million pre-tax loss on the MSSP divestiture.

3.  CVS Health forecasts utilization pressure on its Health Care Benefits segment through 2025, potentially requiring additional premium deficiency reserves; a $448 million premium deficiency reserve was recorded in Q1 2025 in its individual exchange product line.
1. BD's second-quarter fiscal 2025 revenue was $5.3 billion, a 4.5% increase compared to the same period in 2024.
2.  BD's full-year fiscal 2025 adjusted diluted EPS guidance was lowered from $14.30 to $14.60 to $14.06 to $14.34 due to an estimated tariff impact of approximately $0.25.
3. BD plans to invest $2.5 billion in U.S. manufacturing capacity over the next 5 years.
1. CVS Health exited the individual exchange business in 2025, focusing its portfolio on other health benefit solutions.
2. First-quarter 2025 total revenues increased by 7.0% year-over-year to $94.6 billion, driven by growth across all segments.
3.  Full-year 2025 GAAP diluted EPS guidance was revised downward to a range of $4.23 to $4.43 (from $4.58 to $4.83), while adjusted EPS guidance was raised to $6.00 to $6.20 (from $5.75 to $6.00).

1. General Motors Company (GM) lowered its full-year 2025 earnings guidance,  predicting net income attributable to stockholders of $8.2 billion to $10.1 billion (previously $11.2 billion to $12.5 billion) as of May 1, 2025, primarily due to a $4.0 billion to $5.0 billion estimated tariff impact.
2.  GM's projected adjusted automotive free cash flow for 2025 decreased to $7.5 billion to $10.0 billion (from $11.0 billion to $13.0 billion) as of May 1, 2025.
3.  GM anticipates 2025 full-year capital spending (including battery cell manufacturing investments) to be $10.0 billion to $11.0 billion as of May 1, 2025.

1. Moderna reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $108 million, a significant decrease from $167 million in the first quarter of 2024, primarily due to lower COVID-19 vaccination rates and market normalization.

2.  Moderna projects a substantial reduction in GAAP operating costs, from an estimated $5.4 to $5.7 billion in 2026 to $4.7 to $5.0 billion in 2027, representing a decrease of $1.4 to $1.7 billion compared to its 2025 estimate.

3. As of May 1st, 2025, Moderna anticipates several Phase 3 readouts and is advancing up to 10 products toward approval, including multiple oncology candidates; however, some programs like the flu/COVID combination vaccine (mRNA-1083) have been deprioritized.
1. Boston Scientific Corp. had a 20.9% year-over-year increase in net sales in Q1 2025, reaching $806 million more than the same period in 2024.
2. As of March 31, 2025, Boston Scientific Corp. faces potential contingent payments totaling up to $421 million from previous acquisitions.
3.  Boston Scientific Corp. is under investigation by the DOJ and SEC regarding potential FCPA violations and other concerns in Vietnam and other countries.
1. IDEXX Laboratories, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $998 million, a 4% increase as reported and 5% organic growth.

2.  As of May 1, 2025, IDEXX adjusted its 2025 revenue guidance upward to $4,095 million - $4,210 million, a $40 million increase at the midpoint, primarily due to revised foreign exchange rate assumptions.

3.  The updated 2025 EPS outlook is $11.93 - $12.43, reflecting a $0.19 increase compared to prior guidance, resulting from favorable foreign exchange adjustments and a litigation matter accrual adjustment.
1. On April 30, 2025, KLA Corporation appointed Jamie E. Samath to its Board of Directors and Audit Committee.
2. Mr. Samath's appointment was effective immediately and he will receive a prorated grant of restricted stock units and a portion of the annual cash retainer.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in this section of the filing beyond the compensation details for the newly appointed director.
1. Targa Resources Corp. reported record first-quarter 2025 adjusted EBITDA of $1.2 billion, a 22% increase year over year.

2.  As of March 31, 2025, Targa had $890.5 million remaining under its share repurchase program, after repurchasing $124.9 million of common shares during Q1 2025 and an additional $89 million after the quarter ended.
3. Targa continues to estimate full-year 2025 adjusted EBITDA between $4.65 billion and $4.85 billion, with growth weighted to the second half of 2025 and further increases expected in 2026.
1. Meta's Q1 2025 net income increased 34% year-over-year to $16.64 billion, while diluted earnings per share reached $6.43.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Meta had $70.23 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities, a $7.58 billion decrease from December 31, 2024.
3. The European Commission's April 2025 ruling against Meta's "subscription for no ads" model, resulting in a €200 million fine, is predicted to negatively impact Q3 2025 revenue and user experience.
1. CoStar Group incurred a net loss of $14.8 million in Q1 2025, compared to a $6.7 million profit in Q1 2024.
2.  The company plans to spend $266 million on a new campus and acquire 83% of Domain for $1.5 billion in 2025.

3.  The Matterport acquisition contributed to a $13.2 million increase in net loss during the period from February 28th to March 31st, 2025, and resulted in a $95 million litigation accrual, potentially rising to $110 million with interest.
1. Cognizant's Q1 2025 revenue increased by $355 million (7.5%, or 8.2% in constant currency), with acquisitions contributing 400 basis points.
2.  Cognizant's voluntary attrition rate in Tech Services increased to 15.8% in the trailing twelve months ended March 31, 2025, up from 13.1% in the same period of 2024.
3. Cognizant faces ongoing tax disputes in India totaling $3.3 billion.
1.  FMC Corp held its annual meeting on April 29, 2025, with approximately 87% of outstanding shares represented.
2.  Shareholder proposals to amend supermajority voting provisions and to lower the ownership threshold for calling special meetings were rejected.
3. KPMG LLP was ratified as the company's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.

1. Las Vegas Sands Corp. issued $1,000,000,000 of 5.625% Senior Notes due 2028 and $500,000,000 of 6.000% Senior Notes due 2030 via an underwriting agreement with Barclays Capital Inc., BofA Securities, Inc., Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, and Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, expected to close around May 6, 2025.
2.  The offering of the notes is expected to raise $1.5 billion in aggregate principal amount.
3.  The underwriting agreement includes customary indemnification and contribution provisions between Las Vegas Sands Corp. and the underwriters.
